questions.text: First order neuron of the visual pathway is?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Photoreceptor cell The AVP originates in the retina , where the first-order neuron begins with the bipolar cells The second-order neuron extends from the retinal ganglion cells (RGCs) to the lateral geniculate nucleus (LGN) in the thalamus, and the third-order neuron leaves the LGN en route for the visual cortex.

Highyeild:

Causes of visual pathway defect Glaucoma Ischemic optic neuropathy compression of the optic nerve by the tumour.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Lateral Geniculate body Option: B. Bipolar Neuron Bipolar neurons possess an elongated cell body, from each end of which a single neurite emerges. Examples of this type of neuron are found in the retinal bipolar cells and the cells of the sensory cochlear and vestibular ganglia. Option: D. Optic Nerve

questions.text: Horizontal, muller cells and amacrine cells are found in which of the following :
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Inner nuclear layer Located between OPL and IPL. Consist of the following 8-12 rows of cells. Bipolar cells -9 types Horizontal cells-3 types Amacrine cells Supportive Muller cells Inner nuclear layer . It mainly consists of cell bodies of bipolar cells. It also contains cell bodies of horizontal, amacrine and Muller's cells and capillaries of the central artery of the retina. The bipolar cells constitute the first-order neurons.

Highyeild:

Four layers can be distinguished by light microscopy - Outermost layer- Horizontal cell nuclei Outer Intermediate layer- bipolar cells Inner Intermediate layer- Muller cells Innermost layer - amacrine and inner plexiform cell nuclei.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A.Outer nuclear layer . It consists of nuclei of rods and cones. Option: B . Outer plexiform layer . It consists of connections of rod spherules and cone pedicles with the dendrites of bipolar cells and horizontal cells. Option: D . Inner plexiform layer . It essentially consists of connections between the axons of bipolar cells and dendrites of the ganglion cells, and processes of amacrine cells.

questions.text: Congruous homonymous hemianopia is most likely to be seen in the lesion of which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Occipital cortex Congruous homonymous hemianopia is most suggestive of a lesion in the occipital cortex. Homonymous hemianopia involves vision loss on the same side of the visual field in both eyes. This type of visual field loss is suggestive of a lesion posterior to the optic chiasma in the visual pathway.

Highyeild:

Clinical effects of occipital lobe lesions: Visual field defects Cortical blindness Visual Anosognosia Visual Illusions Visual Hallucination

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: C . Complete homonymous hemianopia involves the complete visual hemifields of both eyes and can occur with any large enough lesion posterior to the optic chiasma. Visual field examination alone cannot further localize the lesion in such cases. Incomplete homonymous hemianopia is due to smaller lesions in the visual pathway posterior to the optic chiasm. They are further divided into congruous and incongruous depending on the extent to which the defects in the two half fields match each other exactly. Because of a relative disorder among axon bundles in the immediate post-chiasmal region, diseases in this location produce rather incongruent lesions. Options: A and B .More posteriorly, the axon bundles of the corresponding areas of the two hemifields are more closely aligned and hence, lesions of the occipital cortex produce congruous homonymous hemianopia while incongruous homonymous hemianopia is more likely seen with optic tract lesions.

Extraedge:

Connection of Visual Cortex Primary visual cortex (V1)-Input from LGN and output to all other levels. Secondary visual cortex-( V2)-Output to all other levels

questions.text: Identify the pathology in the Image given below. The patient has the presence of multiple café au lait spots on his body?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Lisch Nodules NF1: 2 or more of the following should be present 6 or more cafe au lait spots each >5mm , before puberty or >15 mm in older patients. Lisch Nodules described as iris hamartomas are pathognomonic markers of neurofibromatosis Type 1.

Highyeild:

These nodules as such do not cause any visual disturbances , but the associated life-threatening as well as vision-threatening conditions.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. A benign (not cancer) growth on the skin that is formed by a cluster of melanocytes (cells that make a substance called melanin, which gives color to skin and eyes). A nevus is usually dark and may be raised from the skin. Also called a mole. Option: C . 2 or more neurofibromas or one plexiform neuroma Freckling in axillary or inguinal regions Optic glioma is the most common tumour 2 or more lisch nodules (least feature), dysplasia of sphenoid bone or thinning of the cortex of long bones with or without pseudoarthrosis First-degree relative with NF1 Associated most commonly with juvenile myelomonocytic leukaemia Option: D. NF2 - the presence of bilateral auditory neuroma , unilateral auditory neuroma along with first-degree relative with meningioma, schwannoma or juvenile posterior subcapsular lenticular opacity

Extraedge:

Few reports suggest a Melanocytic origin of lisch nodules, whereas few suggest the presence of pigmented cells,fibroblast-like cells and mast cells akin to a benign tumour neurofibroma.

questions.text: What length of the optic nerve is it?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

45-50mm The optic nerve is about 47-50 in length , and can be divided into 4 parts : intraocular (1 mm), intraorbital (30 mm), intracanalicular mm) and intracranial (10 mm) . The intraocular part starts from the optic disc and pierces the choroid and sclera (converting into a sieve-like structure the lamina cribrosa) the back of the eyeball it becomes continuous with the intraorbital part. The intraorbital part extends from the back of the eye to the optic foramina. This part is slightly sinuous given the play for the eye movements. Posteriorly, near the optic foramina, it is closely surrounded by the Annu of Zinn and the origin of the four rectus muscles Some fibres of the superior rectus muscle adhere to its sheath here, and account for the painful ocular movements seen in retrobulbar neuritis. Anteriorly the nerve is separated from the ocular muscles by the orbital fat. The intracanalicular part is closely related to the ophthalmic artery which lies inferolateral and crosses obliquely over it, as it enters the orbit, to lie on its medial side. Sphenoid and posterior ethmoidal sinuses lie medial to them and are separated by a thin bony lamina. This relation accounts for retrobulbar neuritis following infection of the sinuses. The intracranial part of the optic nerve lies above the cavernous sinus and converges with its fellow (over the diaphragm sellae) to form the optic chiasma.

Highyeild:

Optic Nerve Disorders : Glaucoma- Is a group of diseases that are the leading cause of blindness. Optic Neuritis -Is an inflammation of the optic nerve Optic Nerve Atrophy-Is damage to the optic nerve

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. 45-50mm - this is not the correct option Option: C. 50-55mm - this is not the correct option Option: D. 55-60mm - this is not the correct option.

questions.text: During a game, a 26-year-old baseball player is hit in the head by a baseball, which fractures the optic canal. Which of the following pairs of structures is most likely to be damaged?
questions.correct_answer: C. Ophthalmic artery and optic nerve
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ophthalmic artery and optic nerve Blow out fracture It results from trauma to orbit by objects like tennis balls, cricket balls, and human fist leading to fracture of the floor as well medial wall of the orbit Usually caused by a sudden increase in orbital pressure due to an object, where the object diameter is greater than the diameter of the orbital aperture Blowout fracture usually involves the floor of the orbit It is of further 2 types: Pure blowout fracture does not involve orbital rim only floor fracture Impure blowout fracture involves the orbital rim and/or adjacent facial bones Signs Periocular ecchymosis, oedema etc Infraorbital nerve anaesthesia Double diplopia- occurs due to mechanical entrapment of both the inferior rectus and inferior oblique muscle Enophthalmos - sunken eyeball May cause injury to the ophthalmic artery and optic nerve

Highyeild:

X-ray (water a view) - teardrop/hanging drop sign is seen in the antrum

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Optic nerve and ophthalmic vein - Option: B . Ophthalmic vein and ophthalmic nerve Option: D. Ophthalmic nerve and optic nerve The ophthalmic nerve is the branch of the trigeminal nerve Rx. Avoid nose blowing Systemic antibodies Analgesics and anti-inflammatory drugs Cold compresses Surgical repair is to be done within 10-14 days of injury
